channel.title: BMS's Blog
channel.description: Because my crap has to live somewhere

item.title: A Library For Creating LED Animations
item.description:
Holy moly, it's been a while since I've written! Well, it's time to fix that. I've done a lot of out-of-band development and side projects since I've last written, but nothing that I've published until now.

item.title: Dealing With Excel Data in PySpark
item.description:
Have you ever asked yourself, "how do I read in 10,000 Excel files and process them using Spark?" I hope not...it sounds like a terrible task...but in case you have, it just so happens I might have an approach your interested in.

item.title: PySpark Timestamp Performance
item.description: In my most recent role, we're using Python and Spark to perform a complex ETL process and to produce data that will ultimately be used to produce some model. item.title: JetBrians DataGrip Review
item.description: Recently, JetBrains released a new product called DataGrip. It's basically IntelliJ for databases, and so far, I love it! Granted: I'm biased. item.title: Perhaps You've Noticed: I Have a New Blog
item.description:
Yep, that's right...I kicked WordPress to the curb and decided to do the whole staticly-generated-pages-thing. When I originally started this blog, WordPress just made the most sense. It was easy to install, easy to maintain, had plenty of skins and plugins available, and just worked.

So, why the departure …

item.title: Vindinium
item.description:
I was recently lurking through the Programming Subreddit, and I came across a post about a game called, "Vindinium."

What Is Vindinium?

Vindinium is an AI competition.  Its a game that is played exclusively by bots.  You could create a bot that takes input from a human player, but the …

I came across an interesting and fun project on GitHub a few months back called FizzBuzz Enterprise Edition.  FizzBuzz is supposed to be a simple programming exercise.  FBEE is supposed to be a joke that pokes fun at "enterprise developers" by terribly over-complicating this problem

item.description:
I've just recently updated my LinkedIn to reflect it, but I left Vanguard back in September to join Coldlight Solutions, a start-up in Wayne, PA.

Holy crap, where have I been?

All over the place, that's where. I've had a lot happen since I've last posted:

item.title: 0 A.D. Wins Project of the Month on Sourceforge
item.description:

item.description:

item.title: Dijkstra's Algorithm in PHP
item.description:
Yeah, yeah, I know what you're thinking:  Why PHP?

Well, I have a fairly small graph (< 650 nodes), so trying to get a C or Java to interact with my preexisting PHP software isn't worth the boost in performance.  The implementation I found can read my graph from my database …
